description: From Middle English reren (â€œto raiseâ€), from Old English rÇ£ran (â€œto raise, set upright, promote, exalt, begin, create, give rise to, excite, rouse, arouse, stir upâ€), from Proto-West Germanic *raiÊ€ijan, from Proto-Germanic *raizijanÄ…, *raisijanÄ… (â€œto cause to rise, raiseâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *hâ‚rey- (â€œto lift oneself, riseâ€).

Cognate with Scots rere (â€œto construct, build, rearâ€), Icelandic reisa (â€œto raiseâ€), Gothic ğ‚ğŒ°ğŒ¹ğƒğŒ¾ğŒ°ğŒ½ (raisjan, â€œto cause to rise, lift up, establishâ€), German reisen (â€œto travelâ€, literally â€œto rear up and departâ€); and a doublet of raise. More at rise.
Related to rise and raise, which is used for several of its now archaic or obsolete senses and for some of its senses that are currently more common in other dialects of English.

verbs.description: rear (third-person singular simple present rears, present participle rearing, simple past and past participle reared)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bring up to maturity, as offspring; to educate; to instruct; to foster.
examples: He wants a father to protect his youth, and rear him up to virtue.

entries.meaning: (transitive, said of people towards animals) To breed and raise.
examples: The family has been rearing cattle for 200 years.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To rise up on the hind legs
examples: The horse was shocked, and thus reared.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, usually with "up") To get angry.
(intransitive) To rise high above, tower above.
(transitive, literary) To raise physically or metaphorically; to lift up; to cause to rise, to elevate.
examples: Poverty reared its ugly head. (appeared, started, began to have an effect)
The monster slowly reared its head.

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To construct by building; to set up
examples: to rear one government on the ruins of another.

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To raise spiritually; to lift up; to elevate morally.
examples: It reareth our hearts from vain thoughts.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To lift and take up.
(transitive, obsolete) To rouse; to strip up.
examples: And seeks the tusky boar to rear.

description: From Middle English rere, from Anglo-Norman rere, ultimately from Latin retro. Compare arrear. Doublet of retro.

entries.meaning: Being behind, or in the hindmost part; hindmost
examples: the rear rank of a company
sit in the rear seats of a car

adverbs.description: rear (comparative more rear, superlative most rear)

entries.meaning: (Britain, dialect) early; soon
examples: Then why does Cuddy leave his cot so rear!

entries.meaning: The back or hindmost part; that which is behind, or last in order.
(military) Specifically, the part of an army or fleet which comes last, or is stationed behind the rest.
(anatomy) The buttocks or bottom.

verbs.description: rear (third-person singular simple present rears, present participle rearing, simple past and past participle reared)

entries.meaning: To place in the rear; to secure the rear of.
(transitive, vulgar, Britain) To sodomize (perform anal sex)

description: From Middle English reren, from Old English hrÄ“ran (â€œto move, shake, agitateâ€), from Proto-Germanic *hrÅzijanÄ… (â€œto stirâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *á¸±roHs- (â€œto mix, stir, cookâ€). Cognate with Dutch roeren (â€œto stir, shake, whipâ€), German rÃ¼hren (â€œto stir, beat, moveâ€), Swedish rÃ¶ra (â€œto touch, move, stirâ€), Icelandic hrÃ¦ra (â€œto stirâ€).

verbs.description: rear (third-person singular simple present rears, present participle rearing, simple past and past participle reared)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To move; stir.
(transitive, of geese) To carve.
(regional, obsolete) To revive, bring to life, quicken. (only in the phrase, to rear to life)
examples: He healeth the blind and he reareth to life the dead. (Speculum Sacerdotale c. 15th century)

description: From Middle English rere, from Old English hrÄ“r, hrÄ“re (â€œnot thoroughly cooked, underdone, lightly boiledâ€), from hrÄ“ran (â€œto move, shake, agitateâ€), from Proto-Germanic *hrÅzijanÄ… (â€œto stirâ€), from Proto-Indo-European *á¸±roHs- (â€œto mix, stir, cookâ€). adjectives.description: rear (comparative rearer or more rear, superlative rearest or most rear)

entries.meaning: (now chiefly dialectal) (of eggs) Underdone; nearly raw.
(chiefly US) (of meats) Rare.
examples: Fred ordered a rear steak along with a glass of beer as he took a seat at an empty table
